definition: An active layer is the layer currently visible and enabled in the pane.This can be a map, program, or portfolio [[layer|EES]].
author: admin

definition: A feature that allows you to view and manage activities such as import, export, and loss analysis.
author: admin

definition: The state of any activity in the [[Activity Monitor|EES]].
author: admin

definition: [[loss of use|EES]], or [[time element|EES]] for residential properties that are not inhabitable. Relocation and temporary lodging costs are considered. [[coverage|EES]] D.
author: admin

definition:
A numerical value or percentage applied to a base analysis to refine the predicted outcomes.

Adjustment factors can be cumulative. You can customize them in your analysis by compensating for variations in company, program, and [[exposure data|EES]].
author: admin

definition: A function that applies customizations to a loss analysis.
author: admin

definition: An analysis of evaluating the total risk across a portfolio, region, or group of aggregate exposures such as [[market shares|EES]] or [[sums insured|EES]] by subarea and [[line of business|EES]].
author: admin

definition: A [[reinsurance program|EES]] in which a reinsurer indemnifies the ceding company for that portion of the loss that exceeds the limit of its own retention for a given year.
author: admin

definition: An [[exposure|EES]] expressed as some sort of aggregate value, as in [[sums insured|EES]], [[premiums|EES]], [[number of risks|EES]], rates, payroll, market shares, loss [[market shares|EES]], and custom LOB, rather than by individual [[contract|EES]] terms or replacement values.
author: admin

definition: The maximum loss that can be incurred by a [[layer|EES]] across all occurrences within each year.
author: admin

definition: The loss resulting from all events that occurred during a specified period.
author: admin

definition: [[aggregate loss|EES]] distributed over a 12-month period.
author: admin

definition: A binary file that contains event-level loss data consolidated by country. It is a vehicle for sending loss data on your book or portions of your book to retrocessionaires for pricing.
author: admin

definition: The value below which the year's total occurrence losses (otherwise recoverable) are not assumed by the [[layer|EES]]. Applicable only to ground-up, [[quota share|EES]], [[aggregate excess of loss|EES]], and [[catastrophe bond|EES]] programs.
author: admin

definition: An online service providing up-to-date information and loss estimates for natural catastrophes worldwide.
author: admin

definition: Data that is supplied by AIR's ALERT™ (AIR Loss Estimates in Real Time) online service which provides up-to-date information and loss estimates for major natural catastrophes worldwide.
author: admin

definition: An object storage service in which customers can store data and pay for the service based on usage.
author: admin

definition: The world’s most comprehensive and broadly adopted [[cloud|EES]] platform.
author: admin

definition: A database that contains reinsurance information you can use to derive and calculate [[market shares|EES]]. To produce the database, A.M. Best compiles data from the year-end annual reports of more than 2,000 companies.
author: admin

definition: Verisk's software analytics suite designed for the reinsurance and [[insurance|EES]] industries. The suite takes loss data in a variety of forms and allows for visual mapping of that loss and its analysis through tables, charts and similar analysis tools.
author: admin

definition: The maximum loss that a [[layer|EES]] can incur for all occurrences within a 12-month period.
author: admin

definition: The loss resulting from all events that occurred during a [[contract|EES]] period (12 months is most common). It is calculated by dividing the sum of all losses in a simulation by the total simulation years.
author: admin

definition: AIR's [[cloud|EES]] branded product used by clients to host application environments on the instance on the AWS.
author: admin

definition: ​AIR​'s software analytics suite designed for the reinsurance and [[insurance|EES]] industries. The ​Analyze Re​​ suite takes loss data in a variety of forms and allows for visual mapping of that loss and its analysis through tables, charts, and similar analysis tools.
author: admin

definition: An aggregate loss distributed over the 12 month period. The annual [[aggregate loss|EES]] distribution shows the probability distribution of annual aggregate losses.
author: admin

definition: The annual [[aggregate retention|EES]] is a value below which the total losses for a 12-month period are not assumed by the [[layer|EES]].
author: admin

definition: The largest loss resulting from all events that occurred during a 12-month period. Used in reinsurance and can apply to a risk, policy, company, or [[contract|EES]].
author: admin

definition: The [[occurrence loss|EES]] distributed over a 12-month period. The annual aggregate occurrence distribution shows the probability distribution of annual occurrence losses.
author: admin

definition: A server that hosts applications or software that delivers a business application through a communication protocol.
author: admin

definition: A parameter used by the application to filter by geographic area(s) and define where [[layer|EES]] terms are applied. In the case of pro rata treaties; this also defines the [[percent ceded|EES]] in each geographic [[area|EES]] covered by the treaty.
author: admin

definition: A parameter used by the application to filter events. The feature allows you to manage which events should be considered in a [[contract|EES]] analysis based on an event parameter, [[peril|EES]], location, and/or condition. Event filtering includes specifying rules and locations.
author: admin

definition: A geographic location that is at a higher geographic resolution than a subarea. Areas are defined using the [[Federal Information Processing Standards|EES]] or [[UNICEDE|EES]] standards.
author: admin

definition: Indicates the level of geographic resolution to be used when analyzing this program. Can be either high (subarea) or low ([[area|EES]]).
author: admin

definition: A fee imposed on members of an [[insurance|EES]] association for certain qualifying events.
author: admin

definition: The average loss across all simulated years in a loss analysis.
author: admin

definition: Maps used in the application to provide a geographic setting for your [[exposure data|EES]].
author: admin

definition: BINS are IDs which insurers and reinsurers use to identify whether an address represents a building, a [[unit|EES]] in a building, a site, or a campus.
author: admin

definition: A single limit that applies to multiple locations in a [[contract|EES]].
author: admin

definition: [[loss of use|EES]] or [[time element|EES]] for non-residential structures. Business interruption losses are based on the expected number of days that a building is unusable.
author: admin

definition: Catalogs are lists of events used to calculate potential loss. Common catalog types include [[stochastic catalog|EES]], [[historical catalog|EES]], and [[realistic disaster scenarios|EES]].
author: admin

definition: Risk-linked securities which transfer a specific set of risks from a ceding company to capital market investors for a specific rate of return.
author: admin

definition: A [[reinsurance program|EES]] in which the ceding company is indemnified for the portion of the loss that exceeds the limit of its own retention per event.

definition: An open data format to facilitate accurate and transparent data exchange throughout the [[insurance|EES]] industry.

definition: The portions of the obligations in an [[insurance|EES]] company’s policy portfolio transferred to a reinsurer.

definition: A device that communicates with a server, such as a desktop computer, laptop, smart phone, or network-compatible device.
author: admin

definition: A network of remote servers that operate as a single ecosystem.
author: admin

definition: Describes applications designed to run on the [[cloud|EES]], rather than on-premises networks.
author: admin

definition: A group of districts within a state in India, used by the Indian crop [[insurance|EES]] market.
author: admin

definition: The portion of the losses to a [[layer|EES]] covered by a reinsurer. Where coinsurance and gross/[[net participation|EES]] are all specified, the participation % is applied to the treaty’s share of coinsured losses.

definition: A simple text file that stores data in columns separated by commas.

definition: The loss a company is estimated to have from an event, excluding any program/treaty terms.

definition: The result of a detailed loss analysis associated with a cedant company. The results are saved at (sub)[[area|EES]] and LOB resolution and may contain one or more perspectives.

definition: Files that contain losses by [[line of business|EES]], [[area|EES]], and subarea for each event. They are used in aggregate analyses.

definition: A [[trigger|EES]] that excludes occurrences from consideration in a loss calculation. If the company loss is above the [[company loss|EES]] maximum value, then the loss value of the occurrence is set to zero.
author: admin

definition: A [[trigger|EES]] which excludes occurrences from consideration in a loss calculation. If the company loss is below the [[company loss|EES]] minimum value, then the loss value of the occurrence is set to zero.
author: admin

definition: A percentage indicating the amount of the total insured property covered by a specified company in a certain geographic [[area|EES]]/subarea and [[line of business|EES]].

definition: Measures the extent to which the losses for the coverages associated with a single location are dependent on each other.

definition: A computing model in which one or more client computers are connected to a central server over a network or internet connection. The server hosts, delivers, and manages most of the [[client|EES]]’s resources and services.

definition: Comonotonic distribution methodology where loss distributions are aggregated assuming that losses are maximally correlated.

definition: A class of code that identifies the primary type of construction for a location, such as wood frame or reinforced concrete.

definition: A [[contract|EES]] gain is an adjustment associated with portfolio analyses.
author: admin

definition: An [[insurance|EES]] policy.
author: admin

definition: Loss attributed to individual reinsurance contracts.

definition: a methodology where loss distributions are aggregated assuming that losses are completely independent from each other.

definition: A processor in a computer that executes programs.

definition: A component of insurable property that describes what the [[insurance|EES]] policy covers.

definition: A value that denotes [[coverage|EES]]-specific deductibles and limits. It can be specified as whole numbers or as a percentage of insured/[[replacement value|EES]].

definition: See [[coverage amount|EES]].
author: admin

definition: The percentage of [[company loss|EES]] of a particular LOB to consider when applying [[financial terms|EES]].

definition: A retired feature.

definition: A geographical data aggregation system that defines country-specific zones. It is used to manage and report on [[exposure data|EES]].

definition: The period in which a specific crop or group of crops are planted and harvested.

definition: Damage factors applied to catastrophe models customize losses based on the experiences of a company.

definition: A third-party database tool application.

definition: The amount of loss retained by the insured; also called [[aggregate retention|EES]].

definition: A list of specific policies and locations, with location attributes such as [[construction|EES]]/[[occupancy|EES]], year built, and replacement cost by [[coverage|EES]]. Contrasts with [[aggregate exposure|EES]].

definition: An encrypted file that contains company losses by geographic [[area|EES]] and [[line of business|EES]] for each simulated event.

definition: A catastrophic event with predefined characteristics, typically used to assess potential losses. There is no probability distribution for deterministic events.

definition: The process of distributing [[aggregate exposure|EES]] data from a coarse resolution to a finer resolution; more suitable for detailed catastrophe modeling.

definition: See [[annual aggregate loss|EES]]

definition: A set of probabilities and return periods that appear in loss analysis results.

definition: Values assigned to a distribution of points (e.g., year, [[return period|EES]], event ID).

definition: Layers of coverage written above the primary [[coverage|EES]] because more capacity is required.

author: admin

definition: A discrete set of related [[exposure|EES]] entities, such as locations and contracts, and their related [[financial terms|EES]].

definition: Unlikely but scientifically plausible scenarios that cannot be captured by standard stochastic modeling techniques.

These may be defined at various levels such as [[contract|EES]], [[layer|EES]], and location, and may apply to its entirety or to specific perils and/or coverages.

definition: A [[peril|EES]].

definition: The value below which occurrences are excluded from consideration. If the industry loss for a given occurrence is below the industry loss minimum value, then the loss value of the occurrence is set to zero.

definition: [[coverage|EES]] by [[contract|EES]] whereby one party undertakes to indemnify or guarantee another against loss by a specified contingency or [[peril|EES]].

definition: The portion of the losses to the [[layer|EES]] retained by the cedant.

definition: To take effect for the benefit of either the reinsurer or the reinsured. For example, when layers are applied to reduce the loss to a given layer, those layers are said to inure to the benefit of the reinsurer of that [[layer|EES]].

definition: the loss reduction applied to [[company loss|EES]] after inuring programs and terms are invoked.

definition: Contracts [[inure|EES]] in series or in parallel (not both).

definition: See [[status|EES]]

definition: A simple, non-topological vector format for storing the geometric location and attribute information of geographic features.
author: admin

definition: A [[cloud|EES]] application and infrastructure environment that serves a single [[client|EES]].
author: admin

definition: A software licensing model in which access to the software is provided on a subscription basis, with the software being located on external servers rather than on servers located in-house.
author: admin

definition: A source program (parent) associated with a subject program (child).
author: admin

definition: The extent to which the losses at two locations behave similarly due to their spatial proximity.
author: admin

definition: An insurance industry term short for individual location-level (spot) facultative (fac) reinsurance. See [[facultative reinsurance|EES]].
author: admin

definition: A database that stores [[vector files|EES]], which are numerical representations of data that capture the semantic meaning of text, images, and other data types.
author: admin

definition: A catalog of events that reflects hurricane risk under average climate conditions.
author: admin

definition: An agreement for federal crop [[insurance|EES]] that consists of a set of contracts between the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) and private companies. The contracts identify expense reimbursements and risk-sharing by the government on eligible crops.
author: admin

definition: An integer value that indicates at which event during the year the [[layer terms|EES]] are to become effective.
author: admin

definition: Refers to the status of the program or [[layer|EES]]. Common status types include: Submitted (default), Authorized, Bound, Cancelled, Quoted, Rejected, and for cat bonds, Investment Status.
author: admin

definition: Series of simulated events based on one or more stochastic models over a period of time. Stochastic catalogs can be used when running a loss analysis.
author: admin

definition: An event whose characteristics are obtained from probability distributions in the [[historical catalog|EES]].
author: admin

definition: A tool for estimating probability distributions of potential outcomes by allowing for random variation in one or more inputs over time.
author: admin

definition: A programming language for storing and processing information in a relational database. https://aws.amazon.com/what-is/sql/
author: admin

definition: A type of [[layer|EES]] condition that applies to a subset of locations within a policy. Sublimits are often used in high-[[hazard|EES]] areas to limit losses for locations that fall within them.
author: admin

definition: The maximum amount that an insurance company [[insurance|EES]] company is obligated to cover in the event of a covered loss.
author: admin

definition: A [[reinsurance program|EES]] where the reinsurer is responsible for the same size of loss on each risk, regardless of the event or year.
author: admin

definition: Measures the average of all simulated losses from a percentile or [[return period|EES]] on the loss distribution through the full "tail" of the loss distribution.
author: admin

definition: The percentage of insurable properties actually insured.
author: admin

definition: A [[company loss|EES]] set or an [[exposure|EES]] set.
author: admin

definition: A catalog of probabilistic events that assumes that the annual probability of a characteristic earthquake occurring on a fault increases with the time elapsed since the previous such earthquake.
author: admin

definition: Loss of use of a structure over time because due to damage, lack of safety, or lack of access. [[loss of use|EES]] is referred to as [[additional living expenses|EES]] for residential properties, and [[business interruption|EES]] for other properties (including commercial, industrial, and others).
author: admin

definition: A catalog of probabilistic events that assumes that the annual probability of a characteristic earthquake occurring on a fault within a given time period is independent of when the last such earthquake occurred and, therefore, requires only knowledge of the mean recurrence time. Compare with [[time-dependent catalog|EES]].
author: admin

definition: The minimum of the [[total replacement value|EES]] or the limit minus the [[deductible|EES]]. If no [[layer|EES]] or policy terms are defined, location values, limits, and deductibles are used.
author: admin

definition: The sum of the replacement values for all coverages.
author: admin

definition: A unique identifier provided by the user when creating a program.
author: admin

definition: Program details.
author: admin

definition: [[coverage|EES]] purchased by a primary insurer in which the reinsurer must cover any risk that falls within a specified line, class, or book of business. See also [[facultative reinsurance|EES]].
author: admin

definition: Characteristics used to define a [[reinsurance program|EES]].
author: admin

definition: The mechanism used to determine when payouts must be made. Triggers define company and industry loss parameters and take into consideration the defined geographic region.
author: admin

definition: A UJF is a user-defined [[adjustment factor|EES]] that applies to ceding company program losses.
author: admin

definition: Universal Cession Electronic Data Exchange (UNICEDE) is a globally accepted open data format developed by AIR to standardize [[insurance|EES]] data exchange.
author: admin

definition: A loss file whose content must adhere to AIR's [[loss file|EES]] format guidelines.
author: admin

definition: A control that enables you to specify the order of [[magnitude|EES]] at which you want to view monetary figures.
author: admin

definition: A standard for identifying servers, printers, and other resources on a network, allowing a consistent access to these resources across different systems.
author: admin

definition: A category which allow you to classify companies and programs using criteria that are meaningful and useful to your specific needs.
author: admin

definition: Files that contain numerical representations of data that capture the semantic meaning of text, images, and other data types. See [[SQLite vector file|EES]]
author: admin

definition: The elevated temperature of the ocean's surface, typically measured in the upper few meters. Warm SSTs are crucial in influencing weather patterns, particularly in the formation and intensification of tropical cyclones, hurricanes, and typhoons.
author: admin

definition: A catalog of events based on elevated sea surface temperatures.
author: admin

definition: Event sets that represent low or very low probability disaster scenarios. See [[realistic disaster scenarios|EES]], [[extreme disaster scenarios|EES]], and [[warm sea surface temperature catalog|EES]].
author: admin

definition: A glossary management system developed by David Wolfe for creating, reviewing, and publishing term definitions across multiple perspectives. Termageddon enables collaborative editing with an approval workflow, version history, and cross-referencing between entries.
author: admin

definition: A proposed definition for a term within a specific perspective in [[Termageddon|Tools]]. Entry drafts require approval from two reviewers before they can be published. Drafts can be revised, creating a version history that tracks changes over time.
author: admin

definition: A categorization system in [[Termageddon|Tools]] that groups related terms together. Each perspective represents a particular viewpoint or domain (e.g., EES for industry terms, Tools for software tools). Terms can have different definitions across perspectives.
author: admin

definition: A combination of a term and a perspective in [[Termageddon|Tools]]. Each entry can have multiple drafts, but only one published draft is active at a time. Entries enable the same term to have different definitions depending on the perspective.
author: admin

definition: A word or phrase that is being defined in [[Termageddon|Tools]]. A single term can appear in multiple entries across different perspectives, each with its own definition.
author: admin

definition: The content that explains what a term means within a specific perspective in [[Termageddon|Tools]]. Definitions are written using a rich-text editor and can include cross-references to other entries.
author: admin

definition: The process in [[Termageddon|Tools]] by which reviewers validate an entry draft before it can be published. Each draft requires two approvals from different users before it becomes the active definition.
author: admin

definition: A user in [[Termageddon|Tools]] who can approve or comment on entry drafts. Reviewers help ensure the quality and accuracy of definitions before they are published.
author: admin

definition: A user in [[Termageddon|Tools]] who has special responsibilities for a specific perspective. Curators can endorse published drafts and help maintain the quality of definitions within their assigned perspective.
author: admin

definition: An entry draft in [[Termageddon|Tools]] that has been approved and made active. Only one published draft exists per entry at a time, and it is the definition that appears in the glossary view.
author: admin
